title: Wealth clients pull a record $9b out of AMP
text:
AMP has reported quarterly results below market expectations, delivering record net outflows of $1.9 billion in its core wealth management business.

The embattled financial services firm reported cash inflows of $7.1 billion over the September quarter, up $600 million on the previous corresponding period, offset by outflows of $9 billion.

AMP told the Australian Securities Exchange the outflows were largely attributed to $600 million in regular pension payments to AMP clients and $200 million to the Protecting Your Super legislation.

That legislation was passed by the federal parliament in February and required inactive low balances to be transferred to the Tax Office, banned exit fees and capped administration and investment fees.

Sources within AMP said the net outflows were also a function of continuing market shift away from retail super to industry funds in the wake of the Hayne royal commission and continuing reputation damage.

"Overall this is a disappointing quarterly update with net flows worsening in the core AMP contemporary wealth management business," said Bell Potter senior analyst Lafitani Sotiriou.
description: AMP's September-quarter results came in below expectations as it reported a record net $1.9 billion outflow in its core wealth management business.
